1.brief: to descend (literally, to go downwards; or conventionally to a lower region, as the shore, a boundary, the enemy, etc.; or figuratively, to fall); causatively, to bring down (in all the above applications)
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
dust (as powdered or gray); hence, clay, earth, mud
a virgin (from her privacy); sometimes (by continuation) a bride; also (figuratively) a city or state
a daughter (used in the same wide sense as other terms of relationship, literally and figuratively)
Babel (i.e. Babylon), including Babylonia and the Babylonian empire
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
a non-entity; generally used as a negative particle
properly, covered, i.e. a throne (as canopied)
a daughter (used in the same wide sense as other terms of relationship, literally and figuratively)
a Kasdite, or descendant of Kesed; by implication, a Chaldaean (as if so descended); also an astrologer (as if proverbial of that people
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to add or augment (often adverbial, to continue to do a thing)
to call out to (i.e. properly, address by name, but used in a wide variety of applications)
tender (literally or figuratively); by implication, weak

2.brief: to take (in the widest variety of applications)
to grind meal; hence, to be aconcubine (that being their employment)
to denude (especially in a disgraceful sense); by implication, to exile (captives being usually stripped); figuratively, to reveal
to strip off, i.e. generally to make naked (for exertion or in disgrace), to drain away or bail up (a liquid)
a lady's train (as trailing after her)
to denude (especially in a disgraceful sense); by implication, to exile (captives being usually stripped); figuratively, to reveal
to cross over; used very widely of any transition (literal or figurative; transitive, intransitive, intensive, causative); specifically, to cover (in copulation)
a stream (including the sea; expectation the Nile, Euphrates, etc.); figuratively, prosperity

3.brief: to denude (especially in a disgraceful sense); by implication, to exile (captives being usually stripped); figuratively, to reveal
nudity, literally (especially the pudenda) or figuratively (disgrace, blemish)
properly, assemblage; used only adverbially also, even, yea, though; often repeated as correl. both...and
to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to impinge, by accident or violence, or (figuratively) by importunity
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)

4.brief: to be the next of kin (and as such to buy back a relative's property, marry his widow, etc.)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
a mass of persons (or figuratively, things), especially reg. organized forwar (an army); by implication, a campaign, literally or figuratively (specifically, hardship, worship)
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
sacred (ceremonially or morally); (as noun) God (by eminence), an angel, a saint, a sanctuary
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity

5.brief: properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
the dark; hence (literally) darkness; figuratively, misery, destruction, death, ignorance, sorrow, wickedness
a daughter (used in the same wide sense as other terms of relationship, literally and figuratively)
a Kasdite, or descendant of Kesed; by implication, a Chaldaean (as if so descended); also an astrologer (as if proverbial of that people
(by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to add or augment (often adverbial, to continue to do a thing)
to call out to (i.e. properly, address by name, but used in a wide variety of applications)
dominion, i.e. (abstractly) the estate (rule) or (concretely) the country (realm)

6.brief: to crack off, i.e. (figuratively) burst out in rage
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
properly, to bore, i.e. (by implication) to wound, to dissolve; figuratively, to profane (a person, place or thing), to break (one's word), to begin (as if by an 'opening wedge'); to play (the flute)
properly, something inherited, i.e. (abstractly) occupancy, or (concretely) an heirloom; generally an estate, patrimony or portion
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to put (used in a great variety of applications, literal, figurative, inferentially, and elliptically)
compassion (in the plural); by extension, the womb (as cherishing the fetus); by implication, a maiden
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
to be heavy, i.e. in a bad sense (burdensome, severe, dull) or in a good sense (numerous, rich, honorable; causatively, to make weighty (in the same two senses)
a yoke (as imposed on the neck), literally or figuratively
properly, vehemence, i.e. (with or without preposition) vehemently; by implication, wholly, speedily, etc. (often with other words as an intensive or superlative; especially when repeated)

7.brief: properly, concealed, i.e. the vanishing point; generally, time out of mind (past or future), i.e. (practically) eternity; frequentatively, adverbial (especially with prepositional prefix) always
to exist, i.e. be or become, come to pass (always emphatic, and not a mere copula or auxiliary)
as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

the heart; also used (figuratively) very widely for the feelings, the will and even the intellect; likewise for the centre of anything
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to mark (so as to be recognized), i.e. to remember; by implication, to mention;  to be male
the last or end, hence, the future; also posterity

8.brief: at this time, whether adverb, conjunction or expletive
to hear intelligently (often with implication of attention, obedience, etc.; causatively, to tell, etc.)
properly, to sit down (specifically as judge. in ambush, in quiet); by implication, to dwell, to remain; causatively, to settle, to marry
properly, a place of refuge; abstract, safety, both the fact (security) and the feeling (trust); often (adverb with or without preposition) safely
the heart (as the most interior organ);
cessation, i.e. an end (especially of the earth); often used adverb, no further; also the ankle (in the dual), as being the extremity of the leg or foot
properly, iteration or continuance; used only adverbially (with or without preposition), again, repeatedly, still, more
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

to know (properly, to ascertain by seeing); used in a great variety of senses, figuratively, literally, euphemistically and inferentially (including observation, care, recognition; and causatively, instruction, designation, punishment, etc.)

a wink (of the eyes), i.e. a very short space of time

properly, united, i.e. one; or (as an ordinal) first

bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)

advice; by implication, plan; also prudence

properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
